review_title: Freedom to do the research you enjoy
pros:
They treat you like a grownup from day one. You're given all the resources you need to succeed but it's up to you to steer your career in the right direction. Nobody's going to hold your hand.

The benefits are amazing: 15% mandatory match into retirement, 25 days vacation, 30 days sick leave every year. You get your own little slush fund for conferences or paper writing or whatever you want.
cons: The soft-money environment can be brutal. Each faculty member is responsible for bringing in his/her own funding through external grants and contracts or be useful to other faculty who have funding and need help. It's a tough way to go, but somehow people make a career there.

job_title: Assistant Research Scientist in Reno, NV
pros:
Some of the best minds in the world
World-renowned
Applied science, not just theoretical
Influential results have far-reaching effects
cons:
Salaries are mostly from very competitive research money - if you don't write and win grants, you have to work for someone who is successful at writing & winning grants, in which case your success depends on others.
 
If you're not on a large, well-funded multi-year grant/contract, you're constantly chasing after smaller grants for partial-year funding. There are funds available to cover grant-writing, but the time-cost is punitive.

pros: Great support (we pay for it though)

pros: Pleasant atmosphere, people are great to work with, decent benefits, working toward making the world a better place to live.  I've been there 10+ years and hope to stay.
cons: Professional researchers have to find their own funding.  If you don't have a project to charge your time to, you have to reduce your hours or look for another job. job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Truckee, CA
pros: Excellent IT-very prompt and never point the finger anywhere else, they just take care of the problem.  Nice environment, facilities are great.  Some really interesting people.
cons: Some people are not to friendly. Due to soft money there is a lot of 'what have you done for me lately' or 'what can I get from you' attitude.  Lack of time used for training-expecting lot's by giving little.

review_title: If you don't mind soft money, DRI is amazing
pros:
Funding opportunities for graduate students are phenomenal. 
Great people, awesome atmosphere. 
Work life balance is excellent, and schedule is generally flexible. 
Practically unparalleled ability to make a genuine contribution to the betterment of the world through conducting high-quality and forward-thinking research.
cons: Compensation. You are paid significantly less than you would be in the private sector for any given work performed.

review_title: Great place to work if you're a self-starter
pros:
Entrepreneurial research - we're only working on relevant topics in hard sciences.  
Flexible scheduling as long as the work gets done. 
You can work on whatever project you wish (as long as it has funding for you). 
There are lots of different subjects, projects, and ideas to chase here.
cons:
No guarantee of funding. This is mitigated somewhat by gap-funding from the Institute (paid for through overhead charges on current projects). 
You can easily over-commit your schedule because there's so much interesting stuff to do.

review_title: A complicated environment to excel in, but rewarding when it happens.
pros: The soft funded nature of faculty positions at DRI is both a pro and a con.  When available grants and contracts are inline with your research focus, the job is engaging, enjoyable, and amazing.
cons: The soft funded nature of faculty positions at DRI adds a level of stress that can be difficult to deal with.  Additionally, you're a post-doc dependent on the funding of a PI, you can feel trapped to the graces of your manager, with little recourse.
